title: Want to help fight hunger in Boston? Here are 5 ways to do it.
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Dorchester Community Fridge supports food-insecure families amid government shutdown and delayed SNAP payments.
Greater Boston Food Bank partners with over 600 organizations, providing two meals for every $3 donated.
Volunteers can help at East Boston Community Soup Kitchen or use the Allston-Brighton Food Train for direct aid.

title: As injuries linger, Patriots rookie Kyle Williams could be poised for breakout opportunity
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots rookie Kyle Williams could see more field time with Kayshon Boutte out due to a hamstring injury.
Offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels praised Williams' readiness, hinting at increased opportunities for the rookie wide receiver.
With Boutte sidelined, coaches consider Williams or taller targets like Mack Hollins to strengthen the offense against Tampa Bay.

title: What songs are on your ‘divorce playlist’?
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Meredith Goldstein explores differences between breakup and divorce songs in the Love Letters newsletter.
Goldstein lists favorite divorce songs, including Sinead O’Connor's "The Last Day of Our Acquaintance" and Outkast's "Ms. Jackson."
Lily Allen's recent album addresses themes of divorce and single parenthood, reflecting personal experiences with actor David Harbour.

title: 10 days after their ugliest loss of year, Bruins are looking like a very different team
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins have won five consecutive games after a significant 7-2 loss to the Ottawa Senators on October 27.
Under coach Marco Sturm, the Bruins improved defensive strategy, allowing only four high-danger chances in their latest game.
Key performances from players like Marat Khusnutdinov and Charlie McAvoy contributed to the team's recent success.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com offers a quiz to test knowledge on recent Greater Boston news.
Peter Chianca, general assignment editor since 2019, manages the Boston.com news quiz.
The quiz covers trending stories and local news developments in Greater Boston.

title: Tripadvisor to cut 20% of staff amid internal restructuring
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Tripadvisor will cut 20% of its workforce as it merges operations with Viator to focus on travel experiences.
The restructuring includes an $85 million cost-savings program through 2027, affecting global staff and contractors.
CEO Matt Goldberg cites focus on AI and user experience following pressure from activist investor Starboard Value.

title: An abandoned tent has spurred a hiking mystery in New Hampshire
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: An abandoned tent in New Hampshire's White Mountains was reported to Fish and Game officials on October 26.
The tent at Valley Way site contained wet gear and food; no missing hiker reports have been filed.
Posts about the tent with car keys sparked online speculation; Apple AirTag tracking attempt yielded no results.

title: Local obituary: Susan Hurley, 62, former Patriots cheerleader who founded CharityTeams
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Susan Hurley, 62, founder of CharityTeams and former Patriots cheerleader, passed away on November 1, 2025.
Through CharityTeams, Susan Hurley helped raise $42 million for nonprofits using athletic events like the Boston Marathon.
A Celebration of Life for Susan Hurley will be held on November 8 at Waters Church Norwood, followed by a reception.

title: Market Basket launches its own beer — here’s where to buy it
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Market Basket has launched its own beer, a collaboration with Vermont's Zero Gravity Beer, called 'More For Your Dollar' lager.
'More For Your Dollar' is a 12-pack priced at $12.99, available at select Market Basket locations in Massachusetts, Maine, and New Hampshire.
The launch follows the recent ousting of CEO Arthur T. Demoulas, amid notable excitement from Market Basket's customer base.

title: As SJC mulls involvement in public defender work stoppage, here’s where things stand
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Over 900 defendants remain without representation amid a public defender work stoppage in Massachusetts, despite a recent pay raise.
The Supreme Judicial Court is considering if judges can grant temporary pay raises to court-appointed attorneys to resolve the stoppage.
State lawmakers and SJC face debate on whether adjusting pay for public defenders infringes legislative powers in Massachusetts.
